[Header]

DEPARTMENT OF THE INTERIOR
UNITED STATES GEOLOGICAL SURVEY
Austin Tex Feb 21, 1887.
WASHINGTON D. C.,

Prof Mc Innis.
Dear Sir:
Did you write me a letter last week
concerning the Geological Survey? If so, I owe you a thousand
apologies. I lost the letter only a few minutes after receiv-
ing it, and could not find it again. I wrote a reply
to "Prof Simms", thinking that was the name on the letter
sent.

I will state that the measure is progressing well,
and that the friends of science and education through-
out the State are rallying to its support. I wish very much
that you would join them. I believe the Geological
Survey, if the proper man is at the head of it, will do
much for your college as well as every other institution
in the State. But much will depend upon the man
and the support he receives. I have been reading
your report to-day. Surely there is much investigation
that could be conducted at your institution. Have
You any Professor of Geology or Natural History? I should
like to correspond with him, for I believe I can make
it to his interest to do so. Please ask for the
letter to "Prof Simms".

Sincerely yours
[Signature] Robert T Hill
